(3) Most MSc:s are not failed PhD:s - in fact, doing an MSc is far
more com=
mon than doing a PhD, and in practice more or less a
prerequisite for being=
 accepted for a PhD, at least a funded one. Me,
and every PhD student I kno=
w, got registered for a three-year PhD
straight away, after having complete=
d a one-year MSc, possibly in some
other university.

(4) The postgraduate =
tuition fee for an EU national, or EU resident,
is about 3 000 pounds/year.=
 For non-EU people it is about 10 000, a
hefty amount. But after having stu=
died in Scotland for four years, you
might be considered an EU resident. Th=
e rules are tricky - an MA
student I know, being a Canadian citizen, manage=
d to get the lower fee
after showing that she was registered with the Spani=
sh authorities as
resident in Spain for the last few years, which she had i=
n fact spent
in Indonesia. But she sure knew how to argue those things. Ano=
ther
friend of mine got both tuition and living expenses funded by the
Univ=
ersity of West of England, even though he's from Norway, which is
oddly eno=
ugh not part of the EU.

I completely agree with what Ian says about superv=
isors.

(By the way, Ian, you mentioned a position paper about modularity s=
ome
time - is that available?)

Julian
